title: Iain Macwhirter  Scotland really is leading the way on climate change  but it won t be a walk in the park
story: Therersquos some doubt, according to the science journal Nature, about just how effective tree planting is as a means of combating global warming. Trees emit chemicals too, and darken the land, thus absorbing heat. But letrsquos not quibble. The Committee on Climate Changewhich inspired last weekrsquos landmark target, is in no doubt that mass reforestation ndash and wersquore talking billions of trees ndash will be one of the major methods of scrubbing CO from the atmosphere.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeScotland is well placed to deliver on this at least. Those barren hills and glens used to be under a dense covering of foliage. The forests were cleared for agriculture and charcoal in the south, and latterly for sheep and deer in the north. So mass forestation is only restoring the ecological default in Scotland.Nice to know, too, that Scotland, on paper at least, is leading the way on meeting climate change targets, having reduced emissions by a creditable % since . This is better than the UK as a whole, which is itself a world-leader in climate control. Scotlandrsquos abundant renewable energy is going to play a major role in transforming the UK economy.Transport is one of the main areas yet to be decarbonised, and every watt of that green energy is needed to make the switch from petrol and diesel in the next decade. Itrsquos long overdue. The internal combustion engine is th-century technology, horribly complex, unreliable and inefficient. Future generations will be astonished that we allowed our city streets to remain sewers of toxic chemicals.Mind you, the Scottish Government needs to put its foot on the environmental accelerator pedal. It is three years since I wrote a series of articles on electric cars after being allowed to drive some of them around Scotland. There were precious few charging points back then, and therersquos scarcely any more now. Yet, the electrication of transport should be a relatively simple exercise.Every petrol station should be a charging station, every supermarket car park, every school and hospital. Wherever cars congregate, in fact. The good news is that no-one who tries a modern electric car will want to drive anything , because they are faster, cheaper, safer and more reliable.Of course, manufacturing any car uses prodigious amounts of energy too, requires many costly materials and produces toxic waste. Electric cars arenrsquot a solution to climate change, but electrication of transport must be, especially micro-transportation. Every city in Europe seem to be turning to those electric scooters ndash except in the UK where they are illegal. Half of the bicycles sold in Germany now are electric. People are turning naturally to more energy-efficient transport so why not give them a push :Climate clock is ticking and now is time for politicians to fightThe CCC report was rather benign on flying. Yoursquoll be pleased to know that itrsquos not being phased out. This is probably because reducing aviation requires international agreement. However, cuts in air passenger duty seem dficult to justy. The Scottish Government wants APD cut by % to attract more business and tourists to Scotland. But Nicola Sturgeon is going to have to bite the environmental bullet here. The optics are wrong. It looks too much like a middle-class subsidy, even though many working-class people swear by Ryanair.Then therersquos the nuclear conundrum. Scotlandrsquos nuclear power stations account for % of electricity generation ndash a large proportion of our nominally clean energy. But they are old and unreliable and in need of replacement. However, nuclear power stations are regardedas a safety issue following Fukushima. They are also ruinously expensive and damage the environment by producing toxic waste which needs to be stored for thousands of years.The nuclear industry leapt upon last weekrsquos CCC report as a vindication of nuclear as part of the de-carbon equation. Big money is going into painting the atom green. But the prospect of the Scottish Government commissioning a new nuclear plant, given the explosive cost of Hinkley Point C, Englandrsquos first new nuclear power station in decades, seem remote. Renewable energy is much cheaper, joule for joule,it can be brought to grid fast enough. We are in a race against time to seeTorness and Hunterston can be made redundant before they fall apart.There are other issues too. Homes need to be insulated, gas boilers are going to have to go. Wersquore told to keep our home thermostats at  degrees, when most of us donrsquot have them. Itrsquos all expected to cost -% of GDP. But what was remarkable about last weekrsquos much-anticipated report was how doable it all appeared. By comparison with the apocalyptic forecasts of the climate Cassandras, like -year-old school striker Greta Thunberg, the CCC sounded like a walk in the environmental park. Nicola Sturgeon insists that cutting carbon will improve our health and wellbeing and the quality of le. Wersquoll all be happier, cleaner and probably working less in our new habitable planet.I hope shersquos right. There was an air of wishful thinking about last weekrsquos pronouncements. But therersquos nothing wrong with accentuating the positive. The problem with the more alarmist forecasts of Extinction Rebellion, who want net zero by , is that they induce not willingness to change, but a sense of futility and public apathy. If addressing climate change is going to involve banning travel, eating no meat, digging for vegan victory and plunging the economy into a biblical recession, as we close down whole sectors of industry, then people will not buy into it. The Yellow Vest movement was ignited by an environmental tax.Scottish Greens: How you can help fight climate changeIt may well be that the climate change targets are still too conservative. According to the UNrsquos International Panel on Climate Change, CO emissions need to be cut faster to prevent the planet warming by more than .C ndash the new tipping point. But the Scottish and UK governments have consistently outperformed their targets since they started making them seriously over a decade ago. They can do so again.Much of climate hygiene is self-evident. The public are morally signed up to it, and while abandoning their petrol and diesel cars may seem a grim prospect now, in practice it is likely to be a liberation. Most cars spend their lives sitting near a pavement losing value through depreciation. With proper public transport and urban alternatives, everyone wins.Vested interests are always a block on progress, but there is now a remarkable consensus, from the CBI to the GMB, BP to the NFU, the BMA to BMW. Addressing climate change need not take us back to a pre-industrial world of squalor, disease and hardship. The human race isnrsquot over yet.

title: three-months-after-its-launch-how-strong-is-the-pulse-of-the-nations-newest-tv-channel
story: Itrsquos a period in which the pound million channel dedicated to Scotland and Scottish content has, at times, attracted record digital audiences, won a quarter share of Scottish viewers, been the third most-watched channel in Scotland after BBC One and STV, reached more people between the ages of  and  than any other channel in Scotland, gained serious traction on social media and, in the best of its content, made good on its promise to give Scottish audiences programmes they wonrsquot see anywhere  and which deal with the issues and subjects that affect, concern and interest them .But itrsquos also a period marked by a wild iance in audience ratings , by whispered rumours of discontent and in-fighting, by a perceived lack of brand identity and by a barrage of negative headlines either questioning the need to have the channel in the first place or pouring scorn on specic programmes, such as The Nine or Catriona Shearer-fronted gameshow Wonderball.:  years of rock and roll - and all that jazzLaunching BBC Scotland in Glasgow in February, BBC Director-General Tony Hall outlined the aims of the channel. As he saw it, they were to celebrate Scotlandrsquos strengths in arts, comedy, science and ldquothought. To reflect the countryrsquos ersity. To allow audiences ldquoto interrogate the things that matter to them and, along the way, to ldquoreinvent public service broadcasting. BBC Scotland, he stressed, would offer space for discussion and debate alongside opportunities to ldquokick back and have fun. It would be about the country speaking to itself but also to the world. It would be local, national and global.In other words it would be a lot of things to a lot of people. Or it would try to be. So, three months after its glitzy birth and with the numbers soon to roll over to Day  of its existence, how is BBC Scotland bedding in  What do audiences think of it  And how well is it measuring up to Hallrsquos lofty claims Steve Carson, BBC Scotlandrsquos Head of Multi-Platform Commissioning, is predictably bullish about its prospects and its track record. To his mind the station is about trying to take risks, giving a  to ldquoa strong range of voices and communities and doing ldquonew things and dferent things. So far the strike rate is good, he thinks. Among the successes he points to are Getting Hitched Asian Style, a documentary series following a wedding planning company in Glasgow, the opening night screening of Nae Pasaran , and Last Breath, a drama documentary about a North Sea er stranded on the sea-bed.Identying a stand-out is ldquolike naming your favourite child, he says. ldquoBut I think Asian Weddings is something I was pleased to see hellip It was quite straightforward but it got into communities you donrsquot often see and certainly donrsquot often see in that sort of context.For an example of risk-taking that paid off he points to Sink Or Skim, which took a fond look at the World Stone Skimming Championship held annually on the isle of Easdale in the Firth of Lorn.ldquoThatrsquos not a subject many channels would have commissioned, but it was a beautully made piece and it was funny watching it go out and looking at social media because people were going lsquoI canrsquot believe theyrsquore doing something about stone skimming. Is this part of their sport portfolio rsquo. But by the end of it the same people were going lsquoThat was really goodrsquo.Sink Or Skim was a one-off but The Peoplersquos News is a weekly discussion of topical events in which ordinary Scots go in front of the camera and have their tuppence-worth on topical events. Those featured might not have the political contacts of a Laura Kuenssberg, say, but they have something just as important: context. They represent the social and political views of people in a spread of communities distant from London and far removed from the Central Belt. Itrsquos another example of the channelrsquos guiding principle that BBC Scotland should be a  for discussion and debate and again itrsquos a programme that wouldnrsquot have aired anywhere .ldquoWe could have done a dferent version of this channel which would have been a lot less risky and done a lot more of what other channels do, says Carson. ldquoA Scottish version of BBC Four, for example, would have been a less risky proposition. But we already have that, so we felt it was important to try new things, go for harder to reach audiences and deliberately take risks knowing that not all of them ndash in fact many of them ndash wonrsquot pay off. Thats what wersquore about.So which risks havenrsquot paid off ldquoThatrsquos like naming your least favourite child, he says. ldquoI think the programmes that we have originated between pm and pm have had a tough time, but again our medium term strategy was not to originate as much there. The Nine has had ratings which have gone up and down, but wersquove always said thatrsquos a competitive slot. But on a digital channel ndash and wersquore already the biggest non-terrestrial channel in Scotland with a three per cent share, which is well ahead of projections ndash audiences will go up and down across the night and the week.:  years of rock and roll - and all that jazzIf therersquos a lightning rod for criticism, The Nine is it. An hour in , staffed by a team of presenters and journalists that numbers  ndash at least in the publicity shots ndash and fronted by Rebecca Curran and award-winning former ITN journalist Martin Geissler, itrsquos the stationrsquos flagship news programme.A lot rides on its wellbeing and it seems a little peaky. It was reported that on one day in late April viewing figures dropped to just . They picked up the following day, to , but even on April , the first day of the inquiry into the Clutha disaster, they couldnrsquot quite hit . From a first night high of ,, thatrsquos a signicant drop.ldquoThe Ninersquos average is signicantly higher than that figure and its reach, which is really important in news, is reaching a quarter of a million a week, Carson counters. ldquoItrsquos offering something dferent. If you wanted to point at a show which is something we wouldnrsquot have otherwise done, The Nine is it ndash an hour long news and analysis programme which looks at Scotland, the UK and the world through Scottish eyes.So is it simply the right show but in the wrong time slot ldquoWersquoll see. Nine orsquoclock is a competitive slot but there is a demand there and people are turning to it. The appreciation for The Nine is very strong and wersquore finding that across the board. You might get some programmes that donrsquot have huge average audiences but the appreciation is strong.In a front page story earlier this month, London-based broadsheet the Sunday Times quoted a BBC source who called The Nine ldquoa turkey. The same source added: ldquoYou canrsquot have a channel that nobody watches. Journalists like their output to be watched and it wonrsquot be long until some of the channelrsquos main talent head for the door. Another source spoke of a ldquopoisonous atmosphere in the newsroom causing behind-the-scenes tensions which could cause key staff to walk. True or   ldquoThat is not the case, Carson says bluntly.Among the keenest watchers of how BBC Scotland has fared over these first three months is Dr Lisa Kelly, a lecturer in television at Glasgow University.ldquoIrsquove been pleasantly surprised, she says. ldquoI think I probably wasnrsquot holding out much hope at the beginning, primarily due to the budget ndash pound million for programming isnrsquot much to play with in the television landscape.To put the budget in context, the BBC is spending nearly three times that amount on the new EastEnders set. But funding aside, Kelly is excited by the apparent focus on nurturing and showcasing new talent. Shersquos also impressed by the choice of programmes and pleasantly surprised at the internationalism of its outlook. One innovation she particularly welcomes is the Next Big Thing strand, which screens short films such as as Meet Me By The Water by Scots-Asian writer-director Raisah Ahmed.ldquoI think therersquos been quite a range of programming. It seems like they are trying to be erse in terms of their representation. So obviously you have Getting Hitched Asian Style and The Nine, which is trying to tackle current debates around issues of representation. So I think it has been quite successful so far.And does it matterratings are low for some programmes ldquoI donrsquot know that it does this early on. I think itrsquos important that we have access to original Scottish programming at a local and national level.There are other challenges, she thinks, besides ratings. One is establishing the channelrsquos identity. ldquoIrsquom not quite sure what its brand is yet in terms of how itrsquos selling itself. I noticed that before the launch it was targeting young people with this notion of fresh and original ideas, but I donrsquot know whether theyrsquoll be able to sustain that.Another is proving that the bold talk ndash of nurturing young talent, giving voice to dferent groups and communities, taking risks and tackling ersity ndash will be backed by bold actions.Wherersquos the Scottish Phoebe Waller-Bridge, for example  And how embedded is the commitment to ersity and inclusion, to actually hearing new voices and seeing dferent stories rather than it just being rhetoric with no change Theyrsquore questions for which Steve Carson has a ready answer. Sothe Scottish Phoebe Waller-Bridge was out there with a project she was aching to make, is he convinced he would find her and commission it ldquoI hope so. And I think we are finding quite extraordinary talent at all levels and also stretching people who might already have done one thing but are now doing something . Like State Of It, which is Robert Florence [co-writer of sketch show Burnistoun] doing quite a scabrous satirical show. Itrsquoll be coming out in the autumn.There is data which can help, however. A measuring system known as ldquosocial listening can analyse social media responses to any subject and from that gain an insight into how that subject is viewed, expressed as the over-riding emotion associated with it.:  years of rock and roll - and all that jazzBBC Scotland set the algorithms running at launch and four weeks later the results came back. ldquoThe strongest emotion in social listening was surprise, says Carson. ldquoThat was really encouraging. So modern Scotland, outward looking, surprising and focussed on new talent ndash thatrsquos the core identity of the channel. SoBBC Scotland is a keyboard emoji, itrsquos a colon and a zero.Three months ago, the channel launched with a Miracle. Whether itrsquoll need another one to make it sing in the long term is harder to judge. As they probably donrsquot teach you to say in continuity announcer school, watch this space.BBC Scotland: The Good, The Bad And The NineGetting Hitched Asian StyleA behind-the-scenes documentary following Glasgow wedding planners Saffron Events as they prepare for a succession of glamorous weddings, Getting Hitched Asian Style proved so successful that it received a repeat run on BBC One and has been re-commissioned for a second series on BBC Scotland. Produced by the Scottish ision of London-based Firecracker Films itrsquos a good example of the channelrsquos stated commitment to programmes which reflect Scotlandrsquos ersity. Verdict: funny, interesting, occasionally jaw-dropping but ultimately humane.A View From The TerraceBorn out of The Terrace, a long-running podcast, AVFTT is fronted by four young presenterswho sit on sofas and talk engagingly about Scottish football. Refreshingly free of Old Firm bias itrsquos fast becoming a Friday night staple for those fans of the Beautul Game who think subjects such as the on- and off-field shenanigans of Partick Thistle legend Chic Charnley or how Eriskay has one of the best pitches in the world are as worthy of discussion as whorsquoll be the next manager of Real Madrid. Verdict: a great signing.Sanjeev Kohlirsquos Big TalkA weekly show in which the comedian is joined by a  of guests for a ldquosideways look at the big issues of the week, filmed in what looks like the foyer of the BBCrsquos Pacic Quay HQ in Glasgow in front of what looks like a smattering of audience members. ldquoI never in my le want to endure another excruciatingly mirthless hour of supposedly witty commentary on the weekrsquos news, wrote one Herald critic. ldquoIt was so awful the only way to hang on to consciousness was to watch what was happening outside the glass-fronted studio. Less trenchant criticism has concentrated on the showrsquos stfness and its uneven format. Verdict: could do better.WonderballItrsquos probably destined for cult status among Generation Z-ers as an endless source of memes, but in the here and now BBC Scotlandrsquos flagship gameshow hasnrsquot been exactly showered with love. Letrsquos not take it too far, though: Wonderball is not, as right-leaning tabloid the Daily Mail has suggested, the worst show of its type ever aired, eventhat paper might like it to be. But you canrsquot say that those who have pointed out its flaws ndash the somewhat complicated rules, say, or the unintentional snigger value of two young men being instructed to play with the blue balls ndash donrsquot have a case. It hasnrsquot been a ratings hit either, with viewership dropping as low as  for one episode. Verdict: not utterly pointless, but not likely to become the next Pointless.The NineA team of talented and accomplished presenters, a  minute running time and a news agenda that blends hard-hitting investigations with quirky or thought-provoking items hasnrsquot stopped BBC Scotlandrsquos flagship news programme taking considerable flak from some quarters. Earlier this month one newspaper talked of a ldquotalent exodus from the channel and quoted a BBC insider who called The Nine ldquoa turkey. Damage has undoubtedly been done as a result: negative news stories about behind-the-scenes tensions and potential resignations may not be true, but they contribute to a narrative of failure which becomes hard to shake over time. What is true is that ratings for The Nine have been disappointing on occasions, though in mitigation its time slot doesnrsquot help. Verdict: a rocky start for a potentially stellar offering that may flourish in a dferent time slot.

title: how-to-plan-your-perfect-tailor-made-holiday
story: Bespoke luxury holidays are a dominant force within the current climate, with more and more travellers setting their sights on worldwide locations and unique pursuits. He will take care of restaurant reservations, spa services, recommend night le hot spots and anything the client wishes. While away on the holiday, he will also be contactable in the rare instance where an issue occurs.Trusted and relied upon, David is a Gold TC . This means based on customer testimonials and sales, he is in the top  per centof  TCrsquos worldwide and one of very few Gold TCrsquos in Scotland.To get in touch and find out more, contact David on   , email david.bishop@travelcounsellors or visit www.travelcounsellors david.bishop----------------------------------------------------------------------------------IcelandairIcelandair operates from the UK and Ireland, serving direct flights to Iceland from five gateways: London Heathrow, London Gatwick, Manchester, Glasgow and Dublin with easy onward connections to  destinations in the USA and Canada, places such as New York, Boston, Washington.When you fly with Icelandair, you will enjoy their unique brand of Icelandic hospitality and comfort. Staff will welcome you with their famous Icelandic hospitality.Alternatively, why not add an Icelandic touch to your trip when flying across the Atlantic  Stop over in Iceland for up to seven nights at no additional airfare. Visit Reykjaviacutek, the worldrsquos most northern capital, and enjoy the islandrsquos geological contrasts with some of the largest volcanoes on Earth and its magnicent glaciers. Start at the Blue Lagoon on route from the airport to Reykjavik and spend your first few hours in Iceland, soaking in the milky blue water. Then head to Reykjavik for a refreshing cup of coffee downtown before plunging your feet into the Groacutetta footbath with a breath-taking view over the Faxafloi bay and neighboring mountains.Now your feet are refreshed, go for a cocktail and a lovely meal at Slippbarinn, the bar at Icelandair Hotel Reykjaviacutek Marina. Fancy a bit of adventure  After a good nights sleep, explore the legendary Golden Circle, bringing you to Icelands most famous natural attractions.Photograph: IcelandairSome of Icelandrsquos best-known jewels lie in the South, which should be at the top of your itinerary.With a well-equipped rental car, you can cover a lot of this adventurous region, with activities like ice climbing, snowmobiling, horse-back riding, swimming and visits to the famous waterfalls.Not forgetting that before you head on to the airport, make a stop at Soacuteley Natura Spa for a relaxing massage before your flight.Visit www.icelandair en-gb for more information.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------Elitsa Nixon ndash Travel CounsellorsPassionate about helping customers create their perfect holiday, travel specialist Elitsa Nixon has years of experience creating bespoke trips. Based in Dumbarton Elitsa has worked under the umbrella company, Travel Counsellors, since last year as an independent travel consultant and one of the areas she specialises in is niche expedition cruises.After settling in Scotland over eight years ago, Elitsa gained a masterrsquos degree in International Tourism Management before joining a major UK tour operator specialising in itineraries to long-haul destinations such as the Far East, Middle East, Africa, Indian Ocean and Australasia.Today Elitsa specialises in cruises, particularly focusing on niche expedition cruises. An increasingly popular way to travel, expedition cruises are changing the face of cruise ship holidays. Accommodating a few hundred passengers only- as opposed to the thousands normally found on cruise ships ndash they take passengers to incredible and remote corners of the world.Expedition cruises are perfect for inquisitive adventure seekers wanting to explore places such as the Galaacutepagos Islands, Antarctica, the Arctic and Australiarsquos Kimberly Coast. These once in a letime trips take passengers to spectacular locations on smaller, custom-made cruise ships designed to navigate icy waters and gain access to places not easily accessed by visitors.As an up and coming holiday option, most travel agents arenrsquot well versed in expedition cruises. Elitsa however has a keen in interest in the specialist holidays and having worked on a cruise ship for five years, is well versed in normal cruise ship holidays too.Whatever theof trip, choice of destinations or budget, Elitsa can help create a truly bespoke cruise holiday. Many people will include land experience in addition to their cruise in order to make the most of their dream vacation and completely immerse themselves in new destinations and cultures.Elitsa is proud to offer customers a flexible and personal service. She is happy to meet customers face to face or can discuss options over the phone or online. With the benefit of working from home, she can work around the customerrsquos schedule to provide impartial advice.To find out more about how Elitsa can help plan your dream holiday, visit www.travelcounsellors elitsa.nixon, call  or email elitsa.nixon@travelcounsellors or simply check her Facebook page @Elitsa Nixon ndash Travel Counsellors----------------------------------------------------------------------------------Thorya Travel ConsultancyIf you have been collecting a bucket list of travel destinations, activities, or pursuits yoursquove always wanted to venture into to but are unsure of where to start then there is a simple solution.With a letime of travel experience and industry knowledge, Birgit Thorya De-Schuster Orsi decided to help others in discovering their dream adventures, and thus Thorya Travel Consultancy was established. The Austrian Canadian Hotel and Tourism Management graduate of Strathclyde University and hotelier wanted to combine her luxury hotel customer service and travel management skills to offer a truly unique and personal service to her clients.Six years on, Thorya Travel has been responsible for pairing numerous clients with their perfect travel experiences, all tailored completely to the personal needs of inidual clients.From weddings and honeymoons, to scuba ing liveaboard experiences, escorted tours, solo or group trips, Birgit can ensure you get the most out of your trip without you having to deal with any of the hassle.Birgitrsquos professional methods and extensive industry knowledge have ensured many customersto seek her services.Once a client gets in touch with Thorya Travel, a meeting or online communication can be arranged to discuss budgets, dates, destinations, activities etc. Once Birgit understands the needs of a client, she will create a bespoke travel proposal listing flight, hotel, and any other relevant options for the client to pick and choose from within their budget. The option to add any extra experiences is also always available. Once an itinerary is finalised, Thorya Travel will create a single pdf laying out all your relevant infoin one handy place for your convenience.Birgit is always conscious of the latest deals and strives to offer all her clients the best prices she can find on the market. Some popular destinations that Birgit recommends at present include once in a letime trips such as the Rocky Mountaineer train journey through the Canadian Rockies which is currently offering a fantastic deal that includes a free hotel stay for  or  free perks for  bookings.Bhutan is another recommendation from Thorya Travel, where Birgit herself has been. A country where progress is measured by Gross National Happiness as opposed to GDP. This spiritual nation believes in controlled tourism which is why all visitors are required to book travel activities via a Bhutanese Government licensed tour operator, who work directly with Thorya and her partners.Thorya is your personal travel consultant. Your journey planner specialized in bespoke travel tailored to fit your personal needs. There to help you put your travel dreams together to help you find the perfect holiday experiencefor you as an inidual, a couple, or as a family, make it into a reality, ensuring you get the most of your experience every time.For help creating your ideal tailor-made holiday or for more information on what Thorya Travel can do for you call Birgit on    or find her online:www.thoryatravelwww.facebook ThoryaTravelwww.instagram thoryatraveltwitter ThoryaTravel----------------------------------------------------------------------------------Visit FrankfurtIn years past, Frankfurt had the image of a grey-in-grey banking city. Happily, those days are long gone. Today, this little metropolis on the River Main is a popular global travel destination, located in central Europe and Germany.But did you know that Frankfurt is also one of Germanyrsquos greenest cities  That there are traditional farmersrsquo markets selling regional produce all throughout the week  That elegant fashion shops may be found next door to the boutiques of up-and-coming designers  Itrsquos true!Frankfurt is a city full of contrasts, a city constantly offering new impulses, new impressions and new experiences.www.frankfurt-tourismus.de en#visitfrankfurt

title: labour-mp-says-richard-leonard-should-consider-his-position-as-scottish-leader
story: Ian Murray said Mr Leonard had to decide whether or not he was ldquoin the best position to take forward the Scottish Labour party.The Edinburgh South MP told BBC Radio Scotland said it was ldquotoo early to saysomeone should challenge Mr Leonard for the leadership, but he not discount the idea.:Richard Leonard faces MSPsrsquo wrath after Labourrsquos Euro wipe-outHe said he had spoken to party members since the election who had ldquochanged their mind about Mr Leonard, despite voting for him in the last leadership contest.Mr Leonard, who has been criticised for slavishly copying Jeremy Corbynrsquos positions instead of having his own, became Scottish Labourrsquos ninth leader since devolution  months ago.Scottish Labour came fth in the EU, slumping from  to  per cent of the vote and losing both its MEPs, including the UKrsquos longest serving MEP, David Martin.It was the partyrsquos worst result north of the border since .At a UK level, Labour lost half of its  MEPs as its vote share fell from . to .%.Senior figures admitted it had been punished for its ambivalence on Brexit, haemorrhaging votes to the Liberal Democrats and SNP.Mr Murray won the biggest majority of any Scottish MP in , getting .% of the vote.But in the European election, Labour fell to sixth place in his same seat, getting just .%.Mr Leonard is due to face a stormy meeting of his MSPs at Holyrood this lunchtime.Mr Murray, an early advocate of a Peoplersquos Vote, said there had been ldquoa huge amount of internal argument in Labour about how to approach Brexit and an EU referendum.He welcomed Mr Corbyn and Mr Leonard taking a stronger line on a Peoplersquos Vote after the party disastrous results, but said it was ldquotoo little, too late.:Tories and Labour panic as election sparks demand for Brexit and indyref votesAskedMr Leonard had been too wedded to London policy, Mr Murray said: ldquoI just think hersquos been too wedded to not having his own mind about whatrsquos in the best interests of Scotland and the Scottish Labour Party.ldquoIrsquom glad hersquos realised.. that the position in Scotland has to change.ldquoIf the position does change, thatrsquos strong leadership. If it doesnrsquot change, or therersquos any ambiguity, then the voters will decide and the party will get what it deserves.AskedMr Leonard or campaign manager Neil Findlay should consider their positions after the election result, Mr Murray said: ldquoItrsquos up to them to consider their own positions. Theyrsquoll decide whether or not theyrsquore in the best position to take forward the Scottish Labour party.ldquoI know many of the members who have spoken to me since the results yesterday have been decidedly angry, and decided that they perhaps voted for Richard in the leadership election and maybe theyrsquove changed their mind now.ldquoItrsquos about time that they showed some leadership and brought that forward."Mr Murray also cited Mr Findlayrsquos decision in February , when Kezia Dugdale was leader, to defy the Scottish Labour whip when MSPs voted on invoking Article .At the time, UK Labourrsquos position was to support the triggering of the Brexit withdrawal process, while Scottish Labourrsquos was to oppose it.Mr Findlay and Mr Leonard followed the UK Labour line rather than the Scottish line.Mr Findlay has repeatedly denied voting Leave in the  referendumMr Murray said: ldquoThe campaign manager voted against the Labour whip to invoke Article  in the Scottish Parliament and is very much a Leaver, but they have to listen to membersldquoThey want a confirmatory vote in all circumstances for any deal thatrsquos passed in parliament. Thatrsquos what the leadership should be reflecting."If theyrsquore not, they have to decide whether or not they should be leading the partythey canrsquot reflect the wishes of the members.ldquoAskedsomeone should challenge Mr Leonard for the Scottish leadership, Mr Murray did not reject the idea, but suggested the timing was not yet right.He said: ldquoItrsquos too early to say that. I think itrsquos early to decide whether anybody will want to do that. I think the challenge for Richard Leonard is... to reflect on the fact voters have had their say, andthings donrsquot change then somethingrsquos going to have to happen otherwise the Scottish labour party are in danger of disappearing for good.

title: scottish-labours-campaign-manager-resigns-following-european-elections
story: Neil Findlay announced he will step down as business manager, party liaison and Brexit spokesman ndash and will leave Holyrood at the  Scottish elections.:Labour MP says Richard Leonard should consider his position as Scottish leaderIn his resignation letter, he hit out at the "toxic culture of leaks and briefings" and "eternal, internal infighting" within the parliamentary groups in Scotland and Westminster.However, he said he had made the decision to step down in March following discussions with family, staff and close friends.He said: ldquoIt has been an enormous privilege to serve the Scottish Labour Party, first as a councillor and then a member of the Scottish Parliament.ldquoI am proud of the work I have done representing my constituents in the Lothian region and of the campaigns I have led in Parliament most notably to retain the Childrenrsquos ward at St Johnrsquos hospital, supporting the blacklisted construction workers, the mesh campaign, minersrsquo justice and support for the victims of undercover policing amongst many others.ldquoI will continue to work hard and diligently on these and other issues right up until I leave parliament.In his resignation letter to Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard, Mr Findlay said: "As you know I have been considering this for the last six months and made my final decision in March following discussions with my family, my staff and close friends.ldquoWe had discussed that I was going to announce these changes at the end of June but, with the European elections complete, now seems like a more appropriate time.:Politics Live: European election fallout continues as Nicola Sturgeon outlines Scottish independence plansHe said he had spent  years as a politicians and it was now time "for a new generation of socialists to come through".Mr Findlay also outlined a series of measures to rebuild the Scottish Labour Party, including having a "clear and easily understood position on the constitution".He called for an "end to the eternal, internal fighting within our party and the toxis culture of leaks and briefings that come from some within the Scottish and UK parliamentary groups".He added: "This self-inflicted harm has to stop - our party members and our leadership teams deserve so much better."Scottish Labour will win again when the focus in on the public not the internal politics of the parliamentary group."He later added on Twitter: "Le is too short to be involved in endless internal battles with people who are supposed to be on the same side."Mr Findlays resignation comes after Labour plummeted to fth place in the European elections over the weekend.The disastrous result has sparked what one source called an "existential" crisis in the party, and Mr Findlay was under fire over his role as campaigns chief.The LothianMSP is seen as a key ally of Mr Leonard and UK Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn.His resignation so soon after the result will be seen as an attempt to deflect criticism from Mr Leonard, who has faced calls to quit.Mr Leonard said: ldquoI am very sorry that you will not be able to be a member of the Scottish Labour front bench but I also know from our conversations that this is the right decision for you personally and in that you have my full support.ldquoYour service as an MSP has been outstanding. You have served the communities you represent with dedication and on the basis of your strongly-held principles."Your campaigns, such as the mesh campaign, the pressure for an inquiry into the policing of the minersrsquo strike, and blacklisted construction workers are a model of what being a member of this Parliament should be about."Through this work you have demonstrated the important lesson that for socialists the purpose of the Parliament is not to be found in the daily grind of procedural arguments, but instead in how the Parliament relates to the lives of working class people in this country."

title: watch-tony-blairs-former-spin-doctor-alastair-campbell-expelled-from-labour-after-going-public-on-voting-lib-dem
story: The Peoplersquos Vote campaigner said he was ldquosad and disappointed at his expulsion, especially as he felt it had happened on the day the Labour leadership appeared to be moving in the direction of supporting another Brexit poll because of the exodus of remainers from the party.The move came after he appeared on BBCs election night broadcast on Sunday and said he had voted Liberal Democrat "to try to persuade Labout to do the right thing".The former Downing Street director of communications said on the broadcast: "I didnt vote Labour for the first time in my le, and it was a very strange feeling."But I felt on this issue, at this time, the Labour Party has let its own supporters down, it has let its own members down and I think it has let the country down in the way that it has failed properly to devise a policy that the party and the country can unite around and the way it failed to campaign."Fair play to Nigel Farages party, they campaigned."He later said he would "always will be Labour" and appeal the expulsion.He added: "I was not intending to publicise this at this stage, but have had calls from friends in the party telling me it is now widely known and likely to be leaked. I have been advised by lawyers with expertise in this field I have grounds for appeal against expulsion and shall do so."I am and always will be Labour. I voted Lib Dem, without advance publicity, to try to persuade Labour to do right thing for country party. In light of appeal, I wont be doing media on this. But hard not to point out dference in the way anti-Semitism cases have been handled."[There are] plenty of precedent of members voting for other parties causes. Some are now senior Party staff. [The] approach also contrasts with our era when TB [Tony Blair] was being pressed by whips to withdraw whip for JC [Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn] and others for persistently voting against Labour in Parliament, and he said No.":Labour Party under investigation by watchdog over anti-Semitism complaintsShadow minister Dawn Butler said members who admitted voting for another party were "automatically excluded".Labourrsquos rulebook says that any party member who supports a political organisation other than Labour or supports any candidate who stands against an official Labour candidate, is ineligible to be or remain a party member and is therefore automatically excluded from membership."Its just part of the rule book. Everyone knows that," she said.A Labour party spokeswoman said it had happened because ldquosupport for another political party or candidate is incompatible with party membership.She said: ldquoThe Lib Dems cannot and will not end austerity. They cannot bring our country together or be trusted to deliver on their promises. They propped up the Tories for five years and imposed the austerity that has devastated our communities.ldquoLabour will do things very dferently, and ensure our society is run for the benefit of the many, not just a privileged few.Michael Heseltine, theformer Tory deputy prime minister, was suspended from the Conservative Party recently for saying he would vote for the Liberal Democrats in the European election.

title: scots-asked-to-conserve-water-to-stop-drought
story: It comes as most of the country is on alert over water scarcity due to low rainfall levels in April and May.Scottish Water has asked parts of the Western Isles and Argyll to make conservation efforts by taking shorter showers and only washing car windscreens and lights instead of the whole vehicle.Those affected currently involve customers served by the Tolsta Water Treatment Worksin north Lewis and by the Tarbert WTW in Argyll are being asked to take steps to save water.Other water conservation measures suggested include using a watering can rather than a hose to water plants, using a bucket to wash vehicles and using washing machines and dishwashers fully loaded.The Scottish Environment Protection Agency has placed a Moderate Scarcity orange alert in Argyll, the Western Isles, and the northwest of the country.A yellow water scarcity alert exists everywhere  except the Northern Isles and south Scotland, which have an early warning in place.The agency has issued a request to farmers and golf course managers in all areas of Scotland except the south region when using water from burns and small rivers to only irrigate only when necessary and at night to cut evaporation losses.It said water sources used for irrigation of farmland to grow agricultural crops, maintain landscapes, and revegetate are at risk of becoming "limited" in all areas of Scotland.The agency also suggested farmers explore how they and their neighbours in the same river catchment could avoid irrigating at the same time.SEPA said: "River levels are still extremely low across western Scotland, particularly in the north-west."Further evidence of environmental impacts and impacts on private water supplies have been reported and therefore a Moderate Scarcity level has been set for this area."Some rainfall is forecast for the north west in the week ahead but it is not yet clear how much this will ease the situation."In each river catchment there is some degree of water storage, which can maintain river flows even when it is not raining.This natural water storage is mainly held in lochs and groundwater.SEP says that when natural storage has been depleted it will take a lot of rainfall for levels to recover.Currently loch levels in the north-west were described as "low for the time of year" following relatively dry conditions.And groundwater levels along the east coast were described as "still very low for the time of year".Scottish Water said that reservoir levels across Scotland were currently at  per cent and "generally good".But it said that despite some rainfall in parts of the country at the weekend, Scottish Water hydrologists say it has not helped to replenish to any signicant level water sources in certain areas.A Scottish Water spokesperson said: ldquoWersquore asking customers in these two areas, Tolsta on Lewis and Tarbert in Kintyre, to consider how they use their water and to follow our advice about how they can use water wisely.ldquoThe weather in these areas during most of April and May has been very dry and there has been a drop in reservoir levels that supply the water treatment works which serve our customers there.ldquoWe have a strong and resilient distribution network to keep our customers supplied, but wersquore asking everyone to play their part by considering what they can do to help us maintain supplies.Scottish Water is to attend a series of events across the country over summer as part of a Your Water Your Le campaign to talk to communities about how to use water wisely.

title: in-pictures-iconic-leith-art-deco-cinema-homes-plan-gets-go-ahead
story: The Glencairn Properties plan for  apartments at the Great Junction Street will keep the distinctive foyer and frontage under the plans.There will be a new-build extension at the back of the propertyoverlooking the Water of Leith.The building, which closed as a cinema in , has B-listed status.The State Cinema, which was opened in  and later became home for a number of dferent uses including as a church and a bingo hall.: Landmark Art Deco cinema to be reborn for Hidden Door festival in Leith#The last screening there was in the summer of  as part of the Hidden Door festival.In astatement, Glencairn Properties said: "Further to full access of the building and structural investigations being carried out it has become clear that it would be impossible to demolish the existing stair without compromising the structure of the external elevation of the retained Foyer building at the corner facing Mill Lane."In the interest of retaining this section of elevation we have proposed to reuse the existing stair and make compliant for residential use.": Hidden Door goes back to festival rootsIt said: "We propose the existing linear window at the stair well, currently boarded up, is reinstated to allow light and ventilation to the stair."It adds: "The primary living spaces will predominantly address the Water of Leith."Long, ribbon balconies will catch the afternoon and evening sun with views across the water, Coalie Park and towards to The Shore.""The long, curving, horizontal balconies tie in with the lsquoStreamline Modernersquo aesthetic and values."A series of profiled perforated  screen the balconies, break up the massing and provide depth and subtle changes of light to the facade."Consultation was held which included a meeting with Leith Harbour and Newhaven Community Council.Glencairns amended plan that keeps the internal stairway in order to savethe foyer, was approved on Thursday.

title: theresa-may-tells-successor-to-avoid-no-deal-brexit
story: Written into a legal text agreed with the EU council in April, her pledge makes it harder for those vying to replace her to claim they can strike a swt and better deal with Brussels.Boris Johnson and other hardline Brexiters have claimed they could force the EU to sht its position on the Irish backstop that bedevilled Mrs May.But European Commission president Jean Claude-Juncker yesterday dismissed notions of the EU falling into line for a new Prime Minister, saying: ldquoThere will be no renegotiation.It came as the race for Number  intensied as the field expanded to  with the entry of two more Tory MPs - junior Brexit minister James Cleverly and the former deputy mayor of London under Mr Johnson, Kit Malthouse.Mr Malthouse gave his name to the Malthouse compromise, a plan to replace the Irish backstop with alternative arrangements, that the EU and Number  said was unworkable.Also standing are Dominic Raab, Michael Gove, Andrea Leadsom, Esther McVey, Jeremy Hunt, Sajid Javid, Matt Hancock and Rory Stewart.Appearing for the first time in public since announcing her resignation timetable last Friday, Mrs May said her successor had to find ldquoconsensus with other  EU states.At a meeting of EU leaders in Brussels to discuss replacements for Mr Juncker and EU Council president Donald Tusk, the Prime Minister admitted the European election results had been ldquodeeply disappointing for the Tories, who collapsed to fth place on a .% vote share.A victory for Nigel Faragersquos Brexit Party has seen Tory leadership contenders sht towards a no-deal Brexit in order to fend off a possible general election challenge from the new party.Mrs May said: ldquoIrsquove always taken a view that the best option for the UK is to leave the European Union with a deal. Irsquom not going to comment on the views of inidual candidates.ldquoThere will be a process of selecting my successor as leader of the Conservative party but I continue to have the view that itrsquos best for the UK to leave with a deal.She went on: ldquoOf course the European election results were deeply disappointing for the party. What it shows is the importance of actually delivering Brexit.ldquoI think the best way of doing that is with a deal but it will be for my successor and for parliament to find a way forward to get a consensus and I hope that those election results will focus parliament on the need to deliver Brexit.Mr Hunt, who has the most number of declared supporters among MPs, warned a no-deal Brexit would be ldquopolitical suicide for the Tories.The Foreign Secretary said MPs would block it with a no confidence vote that would force a general election which would probably ldquoannihilate the Tories and ldquoput Jeremy Corbyn in No  by Christmas.He said he would try to reopen negotiations with the EU to achieve a ldquodferent deal.He said: ldquoThat means negotiations that take us out of the customs union while generously respecting legitimate concerns about the Irish border. Why would the EU leaders do that  Because they do not want the shadow of Brexit hanging over them. Go to them with a shared problem and there is a chance of a shared solution.Mr Stewart, the only candidate to rule out no-deal, hit back at suggestions he was a ldquosuicide bomber who was only in the race to clear a path for Mr Gove.He said the remark was in bad taste given his diplomatic experience in Iraq and blamed supporters of Mr Johnson who were worried by his run.The International Development Secretary said: ldquoIrsquom not running tactically - I am running on principle and because I believe we can uny this country and make it a much better place.He also outlined plans for setting up a salaried citizens assembly of  members of the public who would be paid to work out a Brexit plan instead of parliament. He said he had been inspired by Irelandrsquos assembly on abortion.He told the : ldquoI have a lot of confidence that we are one of the most educated and articulate populations on Earth and thatwe had a citizensrsquo assembly they would be able to do what parliament has failed to do: step back, put party politics aside and look at a sensible resolution to this.ldquoYou need a Brexit deal to last for  years ndash the danger of revoke or no deal is that you end up in a very unstable situation. The issues are set up as very binary but actually in Ireland they broke it down to a whole series of dferent questions.Sir Nicholas Soames, a grandson of Winston Churchill, backed Mr Stewart as the only candidate ldquowho can sort out Brexit, unite our party and restore pride and hope to Britain.Mr Raab launched a campaign video emphasising ldquofairness and said he would like a ldquolegally binding exchange of letters to give the UK a clear exit from the so-called backstop.

title: calmac-campaigners-cast-light-on-pier-that-is-too-dark-to-be-safe
story: Craignure Pier on Mull has weathered the worst of west coast storms, up to  ferries a day and the weight of an astonishing annual , passengers.Now a new dossier of correspondence reveals that it has withstood it all with only the most basic of maintenance.Neglect, say campaigners, means the  concrete and timber jetty is now more than showing its age and earlier this year the structure had to be closed after a piece broke away.Locals and visitors alike are worried and so is Caledonian MacBrayne, the state-owned company whose ferry service from Oban docks at Craignure.After this springrsquos problems a local group, the Mull and Iona Ferry Committee, used Freedom of Information laws to find out just how bad the situation was. It discovered the jetty, owned by Argyll and Bute Council, has lighting that is so bad ferries sometimes had to be cancelled.Ferry committee chairwoman Elizabeth Ferguson said the revelations had been shocking.She said: ldquoAn email of    states: ldquoThe lack of lighting, especially at the pump shed linkspan is causing us serious issues. We had a near miss this morning. Can you please have these addressed as soon as possible Another concerning email from CalMac in  states: ldquoPump shed roof leaking, water dripping into light fittings. Please deal with as a matter of urgency.Fteen months later CalMac raises the leaking roof problem again, emailing the council to say: ldquoAs has been advised for some time now, the pump shed roof leaks into a light fitting, which can be seen smoking inside. This has potential for causing a fire. Can you address ASAP.In October , another email from CalMac reveals: ldquoThe guys are having great dficulty in seeing the heaving lines being thrown during the hours of darkness. The pierhead LED was swapped for sodium, we have repeatedly asked for it to be changed back, but it has never been done.Mrs Ferguson said: ldquoIn the weekly checklists submitted by CalMac between January  and December , lighting faults have been reported on  weeks out of . In other words, over that seven-year period, the pier lighting was only reported fault-free for just  weeks.ldquoPoor lighting at Craignure pier is repeatedly cited by CalMac as one of the reasons for cancellations in hours of darkness and inclement weather, yet the evidence of the weekly checklist and the email correspondence is that not only is the lighting system very poor, but repairs take a long time to be completed.Mrs Ferguson added: ldquoThe port weekly checklists from  to December  report a fender fault of one kind or another for  weeks out of , ie for only  weeks out of seven years did the weekly checklists report that there were no fender faults. Improvements seem to be completely absent. Upgrade of Craignure street lights and pier lighting to LED has been promised for several years, but has yet to materialise.ldquoThe water supply has been leaking without a permanent fix for five years.Craignure Pier is not alone in facing questions over whether it is fit for purpose. Argyll  Bute Council has long faced criticism for the state of infrastructure along a coastline that is longer than Francersquos.It has a multi-million-pound linkspan in Dunoon on the Cowal Peninsula that has no car ferry to service. Its pier at Helensburgh has lost its once regular Clyde ferries and needs pound million worth of repairs.Over the years there has been a pattern of problems, such as the specially built jetty extension at Bruichladdich that often could not handle the fuel tanker needed for Islayrsquos whisky distilleries.Islanders and coastal communities are angry, not least because piers make money. CalMacrsquos Oban-Craignure Service is its second busiest. The emails obtained under FoI, including CalMacrsquos weekly port reports, show Argyll  Bute spent only pound, on pier repairs and maintenance, over seven years while it received more than pound million in fees over the same period.Billy McClymont, chairman of Mull Community Council, speaking after the April closure, said: ldquoThe pier takes in almost pound.m a year. Itrsquos the golden goose and itrsquos a real slap in the teeth that they have spent nothing on the pier.Mr McClymont said the community council was set to join Coll, Colonsay and Tiree, in a new Confederation of Islands being planned to fight for a bigger political voice for islanders, as they claim they have been ignored for years by the council and the Scottish Government.This comes despite good news for the island. A new ferry is needed to handle a  per cent increase in the routersquos traffic as a result of the introduction of Road Equivalent Tarf in .But Craignure is not big enough for bigger ships. A recent Scottish Transport Analysis Guide appraisal stated that the north and south berths at the pier were too short for larger ferries.Meanwhile, CalMac has its own headaches, including an ageing fleet, with many past their lespans and more than  years old.

title: satnav-firms-asked-to-help-keep-left-campaign-for-tourist-drivers
story: But now the issue of tourists driving on the wrong side of Scotlandrsquos roads has become so frequent that local politicians are seeking the help of global tech giants such as Google and Apple to remind drivers to keep left.Kate Forbes MSP, has written to the firms askingreminders can be added to their satellite navigation apps and devices telling drivers to keep left.A number of high-profile incidents involving international visitors driving on the right hand side in the Highlands have provoked calls for more to be done to educate drivers.The SNP MSP for Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch hopes notications can be included in satellite technology in a similar way to warnings to remain within the speed limit.Over half a million international travellers flock to the Scottish Highlands every year, according to VisitScotland, with many hiring cars and campervans to travel around some of the remote landmarks.Last week motorist Alan McConachie, from Elgin, was travelling home from a weekend in Glasgow when he witnessed a motorhome driving on the wrong side of the A dual carriageway.The shocking video posted online showed the motorhome hurtling down the inside lane, forcing oncoming cars out of its way.Mr McConachie said: ldquoI was behind him for miles. Just before the road becomes a dual carriageway he panicked and went across to the other side. There were people flashing him.Skye has also been prone to visiting drivers failing to keep left on their small, twisty roads. In December, local resident Sharon Anslow was on her way to work when she collided with a Fiat  being driven on the wrong side of the road by two tourists.Ms Anslow was left with minor injuries after her car plunged down a steep embankment near the Sligachan Hotel after colliding with the car.The mother-of-three, who is one of Ms Forbesrsquo constituents, subsequently launched the ldquoKeep Left campaign in an effort to raise awareness for tourists driving through the area.A petition started by Ms Anslow, to increase road signs or prompts telling drivers to keep left, has now received over , signatures. Signatories to the petition shared their similar experiences while driving on the island.Val Nash posted: ldquoI have been faced with cars and on one occasion a van, coming towards me on my side of the road.ldquoReminders are needed, especially after a parking area and heading into passing places on single-track road.While Brian McIlroy said: ldquoIrsquom a weekly commuter to the island we need to do everything we can to make driving safer on Skye. [The] #keepleft is a fantastic campaign.ldquoBetter road markings and less cluttered signage. Anything that helps visitors and locals.Following her accident, Ms Anslow said she was lucky to be alive after she was cut from the wreckage of her car by the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service.ldquoThe more people I speak to the more I realise that this is a massive issue on the island and something has to be done before somebody is killed, she posted on the petition page.Speaking to BBC Scotland Ms Anslow added: ldquoItrsquos terrying. I relive the moment all the time and try to figure outI could have done anything dferently, but I couldnrsquot have done.Ms Forbes, the Minister for Public Finance and Digital Economy, has been campaigning on behalf of her constituents to increase road safety.She said she has already contacted car hire companies to raise awareness of the issue.One company, Skye Car Hire, received praise last week after including ldquoKeep Left stickers with their hire vehicles, and encouraging tourists to place them on the steering wheel.Ms Forbes said: ldquoNobody intentionally drives on the wrong side of the road, but clearly wersquove got to do more to remind visitors to drive on the left. Irsquom sure that many will be using a navigation device, whether a GPS, SatNav, Google or Apple maps.ldquoAlready, these devices usually remind drivers not to touch it whilst driving and to keep to the speed limit.ldquoAs such, I have contacted the tech companies to askthey could develop them further to remind drivers to drive on the left.ldquoThis could be done either verbally whilst driving or a warning sign before the start of a journey. Either way, it is another way of reminding drivers as they drive to keep left.The MSP has already met with Transport Scotland, VisitScotland and Highland Council officials to see what small improvements can be made before the peak tourist season.

title: toy-story-4-danny-boyle-and-a-celebration-of-women-directors-part-of-edinburghs-2019-film-festival
story: The  programme, revealed in full today, will open with Boyz in the Wood, and close with the world premiere of Mrs Lowry  Son.Boyle, director of the Trainspotting films among others, will be appearing at an In Person event, as will the actor Jack Lowden, Nick Broomfield, the writer, actor and director Pollyanna McIntosh and award-winning film producer Rebecca OBrien.There will also be a special screening of the new Pixar film, Toy Story , and Brightburn, the superhero horror film.The festival will also feature a tribute to Agnes Varda, the lauded French film maker who died in March.: Film festival launch youth programmeBoyz In The Wood is set in the Scottish Highlands and is about four boys who try to escape a mysterious huntsman.Rian Gordon, Samuel Bottomley, Viraj Juneja and Lewis Gribben play the four boys and the supporting cast includes Eddie Izzard, Kate Dickie, James Cosmo and Kevin Guthrie.Mrs Lowry and Son, is directed by Adrian Noble, a former director of the Royal Shakespeare Company, and depicts the relationship between artist L.S. Lowry, played by Timothy Spall, and his mother Elizabeth, played by Vanessa Redgrave, with whom he lived until her death.In all the annual festival will screen around  new features, including  feature film world premieres,  International Premieres, eight European Premieres and  UK Premieres from  countries in its rd edition and run from  to  June.: Good Omens to be shown at Edinburghs film festivalMark Adams, the EIFF Artistic Director, said: ldquoIt is always important that EIFF reflects the changing face of all aspects of society and culture."With attitudes changing throughout the world it is important that this year the festival has a real European spin and presents a series of wonderful films from around Europe with a particular emphasis on Spain this year."We are also delighted to be able to present a series of striking new films from women directors and filmmaking teams from around the world."In particular this year we have an amazing selection of genre films from women filmmakers, ranging from gothic romance and Western chills through to science fiction and old-fashioned horror."All this set alongside a tribute to French filmmaker Agnes Varda, a women who has inspired generations of directors."British films this year include Bittersweet Symphony, starring Suki Waterhouse, The Black Forest from writer-director Ruth Platt, Schemers, based on writer-producer David McLeanrsquos early years in the music business and the thriller Strange But True starring Blythe Danner, Brian Cox and Greg Kinnear. Danny Boylersquos Yesterday features a cast including Himesh Patel, Lily James, Ed Sheeran and Kate McKinnon.Them That Follow, staring Olivia Colman, about an Appalachian sect, will receive its European premiere at the Festival as will Ode to Joy starring Martin Freeman and The Sound of Silence starring Peter Sarsgaard and Rashida Jones.Skin, based on the true story of neo-Nazi Bryon Widner, starring Jamie Bell will be shown, as will the Cannes  opener, Jim Jarmuschrsquos The Dead Donrsquot Die.: How Toy Story  will be shown at Edinburghs film festivalEuropean films will come from France, Ireland, Hungary, Belgium, Austria, Croatia, Germany, North Macedonia, Greece, Ukraine, Switzerland, Belgium, Georgia, Denmark, Finland, Sweden and Iceland.Documentaries being shown include This Changes Everything which examines the problems faced by women filmmakers and features interviews with Hollywood figures including Geena Davis, Meryl Streep, Natalie Portman, Taraji P. Henson, Reese Witherspoon and Cate Blanchett.The Scottish Documentary Institute will celebrate the art of documentary filmmaking by female directors.The retrospective section, which has already been announced, will celebrate the cinema of Spain.There is a new strand, Cinecuisine, which will feature a series of "special culinary screenings and events."As previously announced the free open-air cinema event, Film Fest in the City with Edinburgh Live, will alsoto St Andrew Square Garden, running from  to  June.Isabel Davis, executive director at Screen Scotland said: "Itrsquos exciting to see EIFF showcasing a number of British debut features, alongside strong international threads, reflecting Scotlandrsquos close affinity with both our European neighbours and filmmakers from across the globe, including Scottish Swedish co-production Scheme Birds."Itrsquos also a chance to encounter stellar filmmakers such as Danny Boyle and Rebecca OrsquoBrien, whose work has brought Scottish stories, unique characters and talent to the world."

title: why-its-time-for-an-advisory-referendum-on-independence
story: Scotlandrsquos fate currently lies in the hands of , elderly members of the Conservative Party, who will select Britainrsquos next Prime Minister this summer without the voters of Britain having any say at all. These geriatric king-makers intend to install a leader in Nigel Faragersquos image, preferably Boris Johnson. He or she will then propel the UK into the self-inflicted turmoil of a No Deal Brexit.This is madness. Yet Scottish voters will be left watching this doomsday clock tick away inexorably till their economic welfare is sacriced on the altar of Brexit on Halloween. The prospect of No Deal may inspire a wartime spirit among Brexit voters, but the vast majority of Scottish voters see this as an act of wilful self-harm by a political elite who have lost the plot.The Scottish Governmentrsquos chief economic adviser says that No Deal could cost Scotland pound billion in less than a year. This on top of possible food and medicine shortages, and transport disruption as the UK severs its settled relations with its biggest trading partner. The longer-term impact of tarfs and lost markets could, according to the Scottish Government, cost , jobs in Scotland.Project fear  Perhaps. But not even the most starry-eyed Brexiter believes that No Deal would be cost-free. The question is: what can the Scottish government, and Holyrood, do to prevent this  Nicola Sturgeon says she wants an independence referendum in late , but by then, the damage will already have been done.I have argued against an advisory referendum on independence for the obvious reasons: Unionists would boycott it and Westminster would ignore it. But the way things are going, there may not be time to wait around for a Section  Order that never arrives. The situation is becoming critical.The Scottish Parliament needs to think carefully today about how it intends to respond to the reckless behaviour of the governing party in the UK.Gone are the visions of a smooth and orderly transition to Brexit, negotiated in goodwill with Brussels. Theresa Mayrsquos likely successors ndash Boris Johnson, Dominic Raab, Esther McVey ndash are behaving like intoxicated football fans before an away match. ldquoCome on you Brussels they slur, ldquo you think yoursquore hard enough.Even those who would prefer negotiation, like the Foreign Secretary, Jeremy Hunt, are being swept way by No Deal fever. No sooner had he said that leaving without a deal would be ldquopolitical suicide than his rivals were vying with each other to don the suicide vest. They yearn for a breakdown in relations with Europe, the better to express their pugnacious nationalism.Theresa Mayrsquos EU Withdrawal Deal, which took two years to negotiate, is dead and another cannot be renegotiated before the end of the current Brextension on October . In fact, one of the conditions of the extension, we now learn, was that the Withdrawal Agreement would not be reopened. There is, as Britainrsquos first female prime minister put it, no alternative.Anyway, there wonrsquot be a Brussels to negotiate with because both the President of the Council and the President of the European Commission are standing down and their successors wonrsquot be in place until November when Britain will already have left.This means Britain is heading like an express train for a clf-edge Brexit in five short months. And, as things stand, Scotland will be dragged over the precipice along with the rest of the UK. The game plan in the Brexit Bunker is for Prime Minister Boris, or whoever, to ignore Parliament, sit tight, and allow Britain to crash out by the remorseless legal logic of Article .Read more: Nicola Sturgeon plans for indyref next yearMany hope that Westminster will get its act together and block this ndash I certainly do. But there is no guarantee that our shell-shocked and confused MPs will be able to organise a successful no confidence motion to bring down the next prime minister and seize control. Nor is there a majority in Parliament for a repeat referendum, evenLabour were to persuade its dithering leader, Jeremy Corbyn, that it should support one. He says hersquoll think about it in September.Sothe House of Commons is now being held hostage by the Brexit revolutionaries, what can Holyrood do to save the day  Today, Nicola Sturgeon will unveil her bill for a repeat referendum, not on Europe, but on Scottish independence. However, todayrsquos bill does not actually legislate for Indyref . It merely provides the technical framework for a referendumand when Westminster agrees to make it legally binding by passing a Section  order. And the chances of that happening are precisely zero.For a start there is no prime minister to receive a Section  request. Theresa May has been reduced to the status of a piece of constitutional furniture for Donald Trumprsquos state visit. Her successor will be even less likely to contemplate breaking up the UK before the UK has departed from the EU. In fact, the prospect of any UK prime minister, Labour or Tory, agreeing to a Scottish referendum until well into the next decade seems remote.Yet, the case for a repeat referendum on Scottish independence is surely stronger than the case for the repeat Brexit referendum now advocated by Labour and the rejuvenated Liberal Democrats. Scots were told in  that only by remaining in the UK could they be sure of remaining in the EU. Now they are faced, not just with leaving Europe against their will, but crashing out of it in the worst possible terms. Material changes in circumstances donrsquot come much more material than this.Enough already. It may be necessary to advance the independence timetable and seek a test of Scottish opinion this autumn. At the very least, an advisory referendum would place on record that Scotland does not go willingly into the Brexit night.

title: Rosemary Goring  Do not rush to judge Theresa May or any other leader
story: The answer, of course, might be a bit of all three, and a lot more besides. Right now, the only thing that can be said with confidence is that itrsquos far too early to deliver a verdict on her tenure as prime minister. Only after a considerable passage of time, when emotions have cooled, and events moved on, will it be possible ndash and fair ndash to assess her role with honesty. Historical evaluation requires distance and dispassion. And, while that sometimes allows appreciation of hitherto under-rated and admirable aspects of a personality, it often also results in a more damning perspective.That said, future researchers seem unlikely to unearth anything exceptionally salacious about Mrs May in the archives. On that front she can sleep easy. Recent revelations about Martin Luther King, on the other hand, by his Pulitzer prize-winning biographer David Garrow, threaten to damage his reputation beyond repair. Almost overnight he has been transformed from charismatic political and spiritual leader to disgraceful sexual predator.The about-turn in his popular image follows the release of tape recordings by the FBI which, on Edgar J Hooverrsquos orders, bugged the civil rights campaignerrsquos hotel rooms. In so doing, they captured King in the act of watching and offering advice while a woman was raped by a fellow preacher. On other occasions they record his involvement in profoundly abusive acts on female parishioners and others, including a prostitute who described ldquogetting scared during a threesome with King and a second woman.These tapes establish Kingrsquos extramarital relationships as numbering around -. Infidelity on this scale among the once-revered is not particularly new, merely confirming that, as with so many supposedly ldquogreat men, in matters of his marriage vows King was a hypocrite of the first order. The real scandal is learning the extent of his depravity and acts of sexual coercion. Garrow admits the material on these tapes is shocking, and ldquoposes so fundamental a challenge to his historical stature as to require the most complete and extensive historical review possible.Cataclysmic new information such as this is what every biographer, who thought they had nailed their subject, dreads. Yet opinion on public figures is always shting, even without a dramatic turn of events. Already attitudes towards those such as Margaret Thatcher and Richard Nixon are turning,not precisely in their favour then with diminished harshness. Several decades on, they are emerging as fully rounded people rather than stock characters playing their black or white, mythologised part in the nationrsquos story.Read more: Is Creative Scotland more dictator than facilitator When it comes to writing political biography that will endure, therersquos no-one to beat Robert Caro, arguably the worldrsquos finest practitioner. Caro, a former journalist, began his literary career with The Power Broker, a groundbreaking biography of New York legend Robert Moses. Moses was the charismatic, brilliant and venal urban planner who had politicians and building contractors eating out of his palm, while the cityrsquos poor were royally shafted. Carorsquos fascination was as much with the nature of power as with the man who wielded it so cunningly.It is Carorsquos magisterial biography of President Lyndon Johnson, however, for which he is best known. With the fth and final volume now in progress, each book has taken years of research. In biographical terms, therersquos probably never been anything to equal this venture. The result is not, as you might fear, a bureaucratic wallowing in the detail of every memo and phone call Johnson made, but a rich account of the presidentrsquos times. Out of this painstaking but imaginative reconstruction the man emerges, illuminated from every side. The facts Caro unearths never excuse Johnsonrsquos ignoble actions, but they do help explain why he was not just a cheat and a bully but also far-sighted, courageous and revolutionary.In his recent book, Working, a sliver of professional memoir, Caro outlines some of his thinking when embarking on biography. Anyone interested in piecing together the jigsaw puzzle that is Theresa May ndash or any other political heavyweight for that matter ndash should start here. His intellectual curiosity and tireless spadework irradiate the lives of those about whom he writes. The result is not a simple conclusion on whether somebody is essentially decent, well-motivated or corrupt, but a living, breathing portrait of their era, as well as them. Nobody in power, after all, got there by themselves. Just as each of us is composed of countless atoms, so iniduals are a sum of almost infinite parts. Mrs May might take some comfort in knowing the ultimate verdict on her career should take all these elements into consideration.

Nobody in power, after all, got there by themselves. Just as each of us is composed of countless atoms, so iniduals are a sum of almost infinite parts. Mrs May might take some comfort in knowing the ultimate verdict on her career should take all these elements into consideration.

story: It had previously been reported the Mr Bercow, who is widely disliked by hardline Brexit MPs, would leave the role in the summer.Read more: Iain McWhirter - Its time for an advisory referendumHowever, in an interview today in the , Mr Bercow said it would not ldquosensible to vacate the chair while there were major issues before parliament.He said: ldquoIrsquove never said anything about going in July of this year."Secondly, I do feel that now is a time in which momentous events are taking place and there are great issues to be resolved and in those circumstances, it doesnrsquot seem to me sensible to vacate the chair.He added: ldquoIf I had any intention to announce on that matter hellip I would do so to parliament first.Read more: Indyref legislation to be tabled at HolyroodEarlier this month, Mr Bercows local newspaper reported that he would not stay on as Speaker "much longer".
